data.title: NDSU at Southern Utah Thursday Before National TV Game Saturday at Iowa State
data.meta_description: The North Dakota State men's basketball team makes an uncustomary road trip this week beginning when the Bison (5-8, 2-2) play Summit League opponent Southern Utah
data.text:
THIS WEEK: The North Dakota State men's basketball team makes an uncustomary road trip this week beginning when the Bison (5-8, 2-2) play Summit League opponent Southern Utah (4-10, 0-3) at 7 p.m. MT Thursday, Jan. 7, at Centrum Arena (5,300) in Cedar City, Utah. NDSU, which ordinarily would visit UMKC on the same weekend, instead will play at Iowa State (10-3) of the Big 12 Conference in a nationally televised game at 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 9, at Hilton Coliseum (14,356) in Ames, Iowa. NDSU's road game with UMKC will come Tuesday, Jan. 26, as part of a three-game league trip to Oral Roberts and Centenary.

RADIO: WDAY-AM 970 of Fargo and Bison Radio Network affiliates KFYR-AM 550 in Bismarck and KRCQ-FM 102.3 in Detroit Lakes, Minn., will broadcast Thursday's game at Southern Utah with Jeremy Jorgenson calling the action. Coverage begins at 7:40 p.m. CT. Saturday's game at Iowa State will be joined in progress on WDAY following the conclusion of the NDSU women's basketball game at UMKC.

TELEVISION: Saturday's game at Iowa State will be televised live on ESPNU. Coverage begins at 3 p.m. with Clay Matvick calling the play-by-play and Stephen Howard as color analyst. It's one of seven televised games for the Bison this year. The first two were at Utah Valley (UVU-TV) and Western Illinois (WIU-TV). Others are scheduled Jan. 15 against South Dakota State (KVLY-TV, KSFY-TV, and Fox College Sports), Jan. 26 at UMKC (Metro Sports), Jan. 28 at Oral Roberts (Fox College Sports), and Feb. 20 at Oakland (FSN Detroit).

ON THE WEB: Live stats and live audio for both games will be available free of charge on GoBison.com. Live video for Thursday's game at Southern Utah will be available by subscription to GoBison.com All Access starting at $7.95 or by subscription to SummitTV on TheSummitLeague.org starting at $19.95.

THE SERIES: Thursday will be the sixth meeting between North Dakota State and Southern Utah since 2007-08. NDSU leads the series 3-2 after a 79-67 victory in the Summit League semifinals last March. SUU's 74-69 win in Fargo broke NDSU's 11-game winning streak and 13-game home winning streak. NDSU won 76-53 in Cedar City last year. ... Saturday will be the fourth meeting between North Dakota State and Iowa State. ISU has won all three meetings by an average of 23 points. The Cyclones won 67-54 in the last meeting on Dec. 31, 2006. NDSU is 0-6 against Big 12 opponents since beginning Division I play in 2004-05.

THE COACHES: Saul Phillips (Wisconsin-Platteville, 1996) is in his third season as head coach at North Dakota State with a 47-28 record. Phillips directed North Dakota State to its first Summit League championship and NCAA Division I tournament appearance in 2009. He was one of 10 finalists for the Hugh Durham Mid-Major Coach of the Year award. A Bison assistant for three seasons, Phillips came to NDSU from Wisconsin, where he was director of basketball operations for three years under Bo Ryan. He was an assistant for two seasons each at Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Lake Superior State and a graduate assistant at Wayne State in Nebraska for one year.

Roger Reid (Weber State, 1968) has a 26-49 record in his third season as head coach at Southern Utah. Reid is in his 11th season overall with a 178-125 record. He was an assistant at BYU for 11 years before spending eight seasons as the head coach from 1989 to 1997 with a 152-76 record and five NCAA tournament appearances. Reid was head coach at Snow College in Utah for two seasons before landing at Southern Utah.

Former North Dakota State head coach Greg McDermott (Northern Iowa, 1988) has a 54-54 record in his fourth season at Iowa State. McDermott was 15-11 at NDSU in 2000-01 after posting four straight 20-win seasons in six years at Wayne State in Nebraska. He moved to Northern Iowa for a five-year stint, where he left after three 20-win seasons and NCAA first round appearances. McDermott is in his 16th season overall with a 275-181 record.

ABOUT NORTH DAKOTA STATE: The Bison are 5-8 overall and sixth in The Summit League with a 2-2 record after a 65-59 home loss to Oral Roberts last Saturday. Eric Carlson led the Bison with 19 points, Josh Vaughan scored 17, Michael Tveidt had 10 and Austin Pennick nine. NDSU beat Centenary 82-70 on Thursday night behind Tveidt's career-high 29 points. Tveidt had 15 in the first half and scored 10 on NDSU's 18-0 run in the second half to go ahead 72-49.

ABOUT SOUTHERN UTAH: The Thunderbirds are 4-10 overall and ninth in The Summit League with an 0-3 record after last Saturday's 53-50 loss at UMKC. Davis Baker led the T-Birds with 20 points, seven rebounds and two blocked shots. Baker, an All-Summit League second team pick, is the team's leading scorer (17.4 ppg) and second leading rebounder (5.0 rpg). He's one of two returning starters from last year's 11-20 team that tied for fifth in the league with an 8-10 record. SUU ranks eighth in the nation in free-throw percentage (.766) through Sunday.

ABOUT IOWA STATE: The Cyclones are 10-3 overall following an 82-75 double-overtime win against Houston on Sunday. Forward Marquis Gilstrap scored eight of his 17 points in the second overtime, guard Lucca Staiger made six 3-pointers to lead the Cyclones with 18 points, and forward Craig Brackins had 16 points, 11 rebounds and four blocked shots. Brackins, an AP honorable mention All-American last year, is the team's leading scorer (17.4 ppg) and second leading rebounder (8.3 rpg). Iowa State ranks fifth in the nation in 3-point percentage (.426) through Sunday and Staiger is 49th individually (.419). The Cyclones play Duke in Chicago on Wednesday.

BISON AT HOME: North Dakota State rolled up an impressive 48-5 home record at the Bison Sports Arena over the past four seasons, but NDSU is 3-4 this year. Back-to-back home losses against Idaho and Wisconsin-Green Bay on Nov. 21 and 27 marked the first time in six years that the Bison have lost twice in a row at home. NDSU shot 32 percent in both games and went a combined 8-for-44 from the 3-point line. Northern Michigan and Michigan Tech were the opponents Nov. 21-22, 2003, when the Bison last dropped consecutive home games.

FELT BREAKS SHOOTING SLUMP: North Dakota State freshman guard Mike Felt broke a three-game shooting slump Dec. 5 at IUPUI when the Bison needed him the most. Felt's third straight 3-pointer capped an 18-3 run and tied the game at 65. He had missed his previous 14 straight field goal tries against Western Illinois, Wisconsin-Green Bay and UC Davis. Felt has missed the last six games with a foot injury.

BIG NIGHT FOR BIG FRESHMAN: Six-foot-9 freshman forward Jordan Aaberg had his biggest night in a North Dakota State uniform Nov. 27 in the 71-62 loss to Wisconsin-Green Bay. Aaberg had season highs of 12 points, eight rebounds, six blocked shots and five field goals. His six blocks were the second most in NDSU single-game history and one shy of the school record. Aaberg had 10 points and three blocks in the final 5 minutes, 41 seconds of the first half to help keep the Bison within three points at halftime, 27-24.

LARGEST COMEBACK IN THREE YEARS: North Dakota State's 15-point comeback for a 63-62 victory at UC Davis on Nov. 24 was NDSU's largest comeback for a victory in three seasons. The Bison trailed 17-2 but tied the game at 24 with a 15-0 run midway through the first half. NDSU led by as many as eight points late in the game, but the Bison committed turnovers on the final four possessions and went scoreless over the final 3 mintues, 31 seconds. The 15-point comeback was NDSU's biggest since 2006-07 when the Bison erased a pair of 15-point deficits to beat Princeton (57-50) and Southwest Minnesota State (72-68).

LEADING SCORERS GONE: North Dakota State graduated its Nos. 1, 2 and 7 all-time leading scorers from last year's 26-7 NCAA tournament team. Guard Ben Woodside (2,315 points), forward Brett Winkelman (1,962) and guard Mike Nelson (1,562) accounted for 66 percent of NDSU's scoring last year. In fact, one of those three players was NDSU's leading scorer for 64 straight games until forward Michael Tveidt poured in a game-high 21 points against Oakland in the Summit League championship game. Tveidt, the only returning starter from last year's team, was the fourth-leading scorer with 9.8 points per game.

BISON PICKED FIFTH IN THE SUMMIT: North Dakota State was picked to finish fifth out of 10 teams in The Summit League according to a preseason poll of the league's head coaches, sports information directors and media. Oakland received 34 of 35 first-place votes, Oral Roberts was picked second, IUPUI was third with one first-place vote, and South Dakota State was picked fourth. Oakland guard Johnathon Jones was voted Preseason Player of the Year. NDSU forward Michael Tveidt was named to the preseason second team.

THE SUMMIT LEAGUE: This is North Dakota State's third season as a member of The Summit League, an NCAA Division I athletics conference that sponsors 19 championship sports. Other member institutions are Centenary College in Shreveport, La., Indiana University-Purdue University Fort Wayne, Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, University of Missouri-Kansas City, Oakland University in suburban Detroit, Oral Roberts University in Tulsa, Okla., South Dakota State University, Southern Utah University and Western Illinois University. NDSU is also a member of the Missouri Valley Football Conference and the Western Wrestling Conference.
